canonical_explanation.text: Statistics deals with the collection, organisation, analysis, and interpretation of data. Data can be presented in ungrouped form (raw data) or grouped into frequency distributions with class intervals. Graphical representations include bar graphs (for ungrouped data), histograms (for grouped continuous data with no gaps between bars), and frequency polygons (plotted using class marks). Measures of central tendency for ungrouped data are: Mean = sum of observations / number of observations; Median = middle value when data is arranged in ascending order; Mode = most frequently occurring value.
rules: Mean = (sum of all observations) / (total number of observations)
Median (odd n): the ((n+1)/2)th observation when arranged in order
Median (even n): average of (n/2)th and (n/2 + 1)th observations
Class size = upper limit - lower limit
In a histogram, bars have no gaps between them
Frequency polygon is drawn using class marks on x-axis

questions.question_text: A collection of information in the form of numerical figures is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Data refers to a collection of information in the form of numerical figures. Statistics is the branch of mathematics dealing with data.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Numerical information collected for analysis is called data.

questions.question_text: The number of times a particular observation occurs in data is called its:
questions.explanation_correct: Frequency is the number of times a particular observation occurs in a dataset.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The count of occurrences of a value is its frequency.

questions.question_text: In a frequency distribution, the class 10-20 has lower limit:
questions.explanation_correct: In the class interval 10-20, the lower limit is 10 and the upper limit is 20.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The lower limit is the smaller value: 10.

questions.question_text: The class mark of the class 20-30 is:
questions.explanation_correct: Class mark = (lower limit + upper limit)/2 = (20 + 30)/2 = 25.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Class mark = (20+30)/2 = 25. It is the midpoint of the class interval.

questions.question_text: The class size of the class interval 15-25 is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Class size = upper limit - lower limit = 25 - 15 = 10.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Class size = 25 - 15 = 10.

questions.question_text: A histogram is used to represent:
questions.explanation_correct: A histogram represents grouped continuous data using adjacent bars with no gaps between them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Histograms are specifically for grouped (continuous) frequency distributions.

questions.question_text: In a histogram, there are gaps between the bars.
questions.explanation_correct: In a histogram, the bars are drawn adjacent to each other with no gaps, since the data is continuous.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Histograms have no gaps between bars (unlike bar graphs for discrete data).

questions.question_text: The mean of the first five natural numbers is:
questions.explanation_correct: First 5 natural numbers: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. Mean = (1+2+3+4+5)/5 = 15/5 = 3.

questions.question_text: The mode of the data 2, 3, 5, 3, 7, 3, 8 is:
questions.explanation_correct: The value 3 appears 3 times, which is more than any other value. Mode = 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mode is the most frequent value. 3 appears 3 times, more than any other.

questions.question_text: The median of the data 3, 7, 2, 9, 5 (when arranged in ascending order) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Ascending order: 2, 3, 5, 7, 9. n = 5 (odd). Median = ((5+1)/2)th = 3rd value = 5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Arranged: 2, 3, 5, 7, 9. Middle (3rd) value = 5.

questions.question_text: The range of the data 10, 5, 15, 20, 8 is:
questions.explanation_correct: Range = Maximum - Minimum = 20 - 5 = 15.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Range = highest value - lowest value = 20 - 5 = 15.

questions.question_text: A frequency polygon is drawn by plotting:
questions.explanation_correct: A frequency polygon is drawn by plotting class marks (midpoints) on the x-axis against the corresponding frequencies on the y-axis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Frequency polygon uses class marks (not limits) as x-coordinates.

questions.question_text: The mean of 10, 20, 30, 40, 50 is:
In a grouped frequency distribution, the class mark is the midpoint of each class interval.
questions.explanation_correct: Class mark = (lower limit + upper limit)/2, which is the midpoint of the class interval.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Class mark = midpoint = (lower + upper limit)/2.

questions.question_text: A bar graph uses bars to represent:
questions.explanation_correct: Bar graphs represent discrete or categorical data with separated bars (gaps between bars).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bar graphs are used for discrete/categorical data, while histograms are for continuous grouped data.

questions.question_text: The median of the data 4, 8, 12, 16 (even number of observations) is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: n = 4 (even). Median = average of 2nd and 3rd values = (8+12)/2 = 10.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For even n: median = average of (n/2)th and (n/2+1)th observations = (8+12)/2 = 10.

questions.question_text: The upper limit of the class 30-40 is:
questions.explanation_correct: In the class interval 30-40, the upper limit is 40 and the lower limit is 30.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Upper limit = 40 (the larger value in the class interval).

questions.question_text: If the mean of 5 observations is 12, the sum of observations is:
questions.explanation_correct: Mean = Sum/n. 12 = Sum/5. Sum = 60.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sum = Mean x n = 12 x 5 = 60.

questions.question_text: Data that has been arranged in groups or classes is called:
questions.explanation_correct: When data is organised into class intervals and frequencies, it is called grouped data.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Grouped data = data arranged into class intervals with frequencies.

questions.question_text: A frequency polygon can be drawn from a histogram by joining the midpoints of the tops of the bars.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, a frequency polygon is obtained by joining the midpoints (class marks) at the top of each histogram bar and extending to the x-axis at both ends.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The tops of histogram bars are joined at their midpoints to form a frequency polygon.

questions.question_text: The mean of 6, 8, x, 14, 18 is 10. The value of x is:
The median of 12, 15, 8, 20, 6, 18, 10 is:
questions.explanation_correct: Ascending order: 6, 8, 10, 12, 15, 18, 20. n = 7 (odd). Median = 4th value = 12.

questions.question_text: The mode of 5, 7, 9, 7, 5, 7, 2, 7 is:
questions.explanation_correct: 7 appears 4 times (most frequent). Mode = 7.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Frequency of 7 = 4, frequency of 5 = 2. Mode = 7 (highest frequency).

questions.question_text: For the class intervals 0-10, 10-20, 20-30, the class marks are:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Class mark = midpoint of each interval: 5, 15, 25.

questions.question_text: The mean of 20 observations is 15. If each observation is increased by 3, the new mean is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: If each observation increases by 3, the mean also increases by 3: new mean = 15 + 3 = 18.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adding a constant to every observation shifts the mean by the same constant: 15 + 3 = 18.

questions.question_text: In a histogram, the width of each bar represents:

options.text: The class size (width of the class interval)

questions.explanation_correct: In a histogram, the width of each bar equals the class size (upper limit - lower limit), and the height represents the frequency.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bar width = class size. Bar height = frequency (for equal class sizes).

questions.question_text: The mean of first 10 natural numbers is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sum of first 10 natural numbers = 10(11)/2 = 55. Mean = 55/10 = 5.5.

questions.question_text: To convert discontinuous class intervals like 1-10, 11-20, 21-30 to continuous, we adjust by:

options.text: Subtracting 0.5 from lower limit and adding 0.5 to upper limit

questions.explanation_correct: Adjustment factor = (11-10)/2 = 0.5. Subtract 0.5 from lower limits and add 0.5 to upper limits: 0.5-10.5, 10.5-20.5, 20.5-30.5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: To make classes continuous: lower limit - 0.5 and upper limit + 0.5.

questions.explanation_correct: Sum = 2+3+3+4+5+5+5+6+6 = 39. Mean = 39/9 = 4.33 (approx). Mode = 5 (appears 3 times, most frequent).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mean = 39/9 = 4.33. Mode = 5 (frequency 3).

questions.question_text: A bar graph and a histogram look the same for all types of data.
questions.explanation_correct: A bar graph has gaps between bars (for discrete/categorical data) while a histogram has no gaps (for continuous grouped data). They look different.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bar graphs have gaps; histograms do not. They represent different types of data.

questions.question_text: If the mean of 5 numbers is 20 and the mean of 3 of them is 15, the mean of the other 2 is:
questions.explanation_correct: Total sum = 5 x 20 = 100. Sum of 3 numbers = 3 x 15 = 45. Sum of other 2 = 100 - 45 = 55. Mean = 55/2 = 27.5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sum of 2 numbers = 100 - 45 = 55. Mean = 55/2 = 27.5.

questions.question_text: The class mark of the class interval 35-45 is ___.
The median of 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12 is:
questions.explanation_correct: n = 6 (even). Median = average of 3rd and 4th values = (6+8)/2 = 7.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For even n = 6: median = (3rd + 4th)/2 = (6+8)/2 = 7.

questions.question_text: In a frequency polygon, the graph starts and ends at:

options.text: The first and last class marks
The x-axis, at the midpoints of imaginary classes before the first and after the last class

questions.explanation_correct: A frequency polygon starts and ends at the x-axis by extending to midpoints of imaginary classes (with zero frequency) before the first and after the last class.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The polygon is closed at both ends by connecting to the x-axis at the class marks of imaginary classes with zero frequency.

questions.question_text: If the mean of 10 observations is 25 and each observation is multiplied by 2, the new mean is:
questions.explanation_correct: When each observation is multiplied by 2, the mean is also multiplied by 2: new mean = 25 x 2 = 50.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Multiplying all observations by k multiplies the mean by k: 25 x 2 = 50.

questions.question_text: The number of class intervals with class size 5 needed to cover data from 10 to 60 is:
questions.explanation_correct: Range = 60 - 10 = 50. Number of classes = 50/5 = 10.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Number of classes = range / class size = 50/5 = 10.

questions.question_text: If the mode of a dataset is 15 and the mean is 20, the median is approximately 18.33.
questions.explanation_correct: Using the empirical relationship: Mode = 3 x Median - 2 x Mean. 15 = 3 x Median - 40. 3 x Median = 55. Median = 55/3 = 18.33 (approx).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Empirical relation: Mode = 3(Median) - 2(Mean). 15 = 3M - 40. M = 55/3 = 18.33.

questions.question_text: For drawing a histogram with unequal class sizes, we should plot:
questions.explanation_correct: With unequal class sizes, we plot frequency density (frequency/class width) to ensure areas represent frequencies correctly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Frequency density adjusts for different class widths so the bar area (not height) represents frequency.

questions.question_text: In a grouped frequency distribution with classes 0-10, 10-20, 20-30, the observation 20 belongs to the class:
questions.explanation_correct: In continuous frequency distributions, the convention is that the upper limit is excluded from that class and included in the next. So 20 belongs to 20-30.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Convention: upper limit is excluded. So 20 belongs to the class 20-30, not 10-20.

questions.question_text: The runs scored by 11 players are: 6, 15, 120, 50, 100, 80, 10, 15, 8, 15, 5. The mode and median are:
questions.explanation_correct: Mode = 15 (appears 3 times). Ascending: 5, 6, 8, 10, 15, 15, 15, 50, 80, 100, 120. Median = 6th value = 15.

questions.question_text: The mean of 50 observations is 36. If two observations 28 and 44 are removed, the mean of the remaining 48 observations is:
questions.explanation_correct: Total sum = 50 x 36 = 1800. Sum removed = 28 + 44 = 72. New sum = 1800 - 72 = 1728. New mean = 1728/48 = 36.

questions.question_text: The class marks of a frequency distribution are 10, 15, 20, 25, 30. The class size is:
questions.explanation_correct: The difference between consecutive class marks = 15 - 10 = 5. The class size equals this difference.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Class size = difference between consecutive class marks = 15 - 10 = 5.

questions.question_text: The mean of 8, 12, 15, x, 20, 25 is 16. The value of x is ___.
The total area of all bars in a histogram represents:

options.text: The total frequency (for equal class widths)

questions.explanation_correct: For equal class widths, each bar area = width x height = class size x frequency. Total area proportional to total frequency. For frequency density histograms, total area = total frequency exactly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The total area under a histogram represents the total frequency of all observations.

questions.question_text: A data set has 15 observations in ascending order. The median is the:
questions.explanation_correct: n = 15 (odd). Median = ((15+1)/2)th = 8th observation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Median position for odd n = (n+1)/2 = 16/2 = 8th observation.

questions.question_text: The mean of 5 numbers is 18. If one number is excluded, the mean of remaining 4 is 16. The excluded number is:
questions.explanation_correct: Total = 5 x 18 = 90. Sum of remaining 4 = 4 x 16 = 64. Excluded number = 90 - 64 = 26.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Excluded number = 90 - 64 = 26.

questions.question_text: If the class marks of a distribution are 6, 12, 18, 24, the corresponding class intervals are:
questions.explanation_correct: Class size = 12 - 6 = 6. Half class size = 3. Class intervals: (6-3)-(6+3) = 3-9, (12-3)-(12+3) = 9-15, etc.

questions.question_text: A data set can have more than one mode.
questions.explanation_correct: If two or more values have the same highest frequency, the data is bimodal or multimodal, having more than one mode.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Data can be bimodal (2 modes) or multimodal (3+ modes) if multiple values share the highest frequency.

questions.question_text: The marks of 9 students are: 35, 40, 42, 38, 45, 50, 42, 48, 42. The mean, median, and mode respectively are:
A frequency polygon can be drawn independently without first drawing a:

options.text: Neither - it always needs a histogram

questions.explanation_correct: A frequency polygon can be drawn independently by plotting class marks against frequencies and joining the points. It does not require drawing a histogram first, though it can be drawn from one.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A frequency polygon can be drawn independently by plotting (class mark, frequency) pairs without needing a histogram.
